name: Muslim Advocates
mission: TO PROMOTE EQUALITY, LIBERTY AND JUSTICE FOR ALL, BY PROVIDING LEADERSHIP THROUGH LEGAL ADVOCACY, POLICY ENGAGEMENT AND CIVIC EDUCATION AND BY SERVING A...
theoryOfChange: Muslim Advocates' Annual Report outlines their strategic framework. It states their commitment to "leveraging our nationally recognized legal-advocacy skills to help Muslims and other historically marginalized groups enjoy the full spectrum of American civic life with dignity." They measure their impact against "three pillars: building community power, dismantling discriminatory systems, and demanding shared wellbeing." Their strategies include "High-impact, precedent-setting legal advocacy that reflects the demands of social movements and leads to systemic change," "Policy engagement at the federal, state, and local levels that hold policymakers accountable to the demands of the diverse, intersecting spectrum of Muslim communities," "Advocacy that builds power by providing analysis, training, and resources," and "Narrative-shifting communications work that disrupts the oppressive framing of Muslim identities." The report also details their mission and vision to "promote justice and equity while protecting the diverse spectrum of Muslim communities from anti-Muslim targeting in all of its forms."
zakatClaimEvidence: Gifts made to Muslim Advocates are Zakat-eligible, more information is available. (Source: https://muslimadvocates.org/donate/)

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 60/100 score, reflecting a stable financial foundation balanced by moderate program spending and fundraising costs. While it addresses urgent civil rights issues, limited data availability impacts the overall confidence rating.

Increase the program expense ratio, currently at 54.9%, to direct more funds toward core services
Enhance data transparency to improve overall confidence scores

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 29/50, the charity demonstrates a track record in high-urgency advocacy work, yet shows a lower fit for traditional Muslim donors compared to direct-service charities [1][7]. The organization is zakat-eligible, providing a specific avenue for faith-based giving toward justice and liberty [8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization focuses on capacity building and legal advocacy, though its impact score of 31/50 reflects a moderate program expense ratio of 54.9% [1][2]. While it holds 7.8 months of working capital, the lack of third-party impact verification and a low data confidence score of 0.3 suggest a need for more transparent reporting on program outcomes [2][3].

baseline_narrative.summary: Based in Washington, D.C., Muslim Advocates provides legal representation and civic education to protect the rights of all Americans [1][2]. The organization reported a total revenue of $992,892 and is recognized as zakat-eligible for donors seeking to support civil rights initiatives [2][8].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize systemic civil rights protections and legal defense for the American Muslim community over direct social services.
donor_motivations: Want to support legal challenges against discriminatory policies
Value the protection of Islamic institutional infrastructure
Seek to fulfill zakat through advocacy in the path of Allah (fisabilillah)
giving_considerations: High overhead costs are typical for complex legal advocacy but exceed peer averages here
Recent revenue declines may suggest a period of organizational transition
Impact is measured in legal precedents and policy shifts rather than individual aid units
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-efficiency direct aid (e.g., food or medical) or those who require rigorous cost-per-beneficiary metrics.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear strategic framework but a lack of independent, third-party evaluations of long-term outcomes.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The organization creates impact by providing leadership through legal advocacy and policy engagement to ensure equality for all.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence in advocacy helps donors understand how legal victories translate into broader community safety and freedom.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Significant revenue declines and a large funding gap indicate a high capacity to absorb new donations to restore program scale.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains <cite id="5">7.8 months of working capital</cite>, ensuring it can sustain long-term legal battles despite revenue volatility.
The organization is governed by an <cite id="9">independent board of 10 members</cite>, ensuring oversight and strategic leadership.
Muslim Advocates has a track record of securing <cite id="10">legal awards and settlements</cite> to protect civil rights.

strengths_deep_dive: Muslim Advocates distinguishes itself through its dual focus on individual litigation and systemic policy change. By maintaining <cite id="11">100% independent board members</cite>, the organization ensures that its advocacy remains focused on its core mission of equality and justice. Their financial strategy has prioritized <cite id="5">maintaining a solid liquidity position</cite>, which is critical for an advocacy organization that may face unpredictable legal costs. Furthermore, their <cite id="8">Muslim Charities Accreditation Program</cite> provides a unique service to the community by helping other non-profits navigate complex regulatory environments.
rich_narrative.summary: Muslim Advocates is a national civil rights organization that utilizes <cite id="1">legal advocacy, policy engagement, and civic education</cite> to protect the rights of Muslim Americans. Based in Washington, D.C., the organization operates as a high-urgency advocacy group, focusing on <cite id="2">legal representation and protecting charities</cite> from discriminatory practices. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $992,892</cite>, a significant decrease from previous years as reflected in a <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of -62.5%</cite>. Despite this contraction, the organization maintains a <cite id="5">resilient liquidity position with 7.8 months of working capital</cite>, providing a buffer for its ongoing litigation and policy work. Muslim Advocates is <cite id="6">recognized as zakat-eligible</cite>, specifically serving categories such as <cite id="7">fisabilillah (in the path of Allah)</cite> through its work defending religious freedom and civil liberties. Its program portfolio includes the <cite id="8">Muslim Charities Accreditation Program (MCAP)</cite> and the Keeping the Faith Database, which are designed to strengthen the institutional capacity of the American Muslim community.
